# What is Quarto?



## TLDR

- Quarto enables you to weave together content and executable code into a finished document.

- Highlight Quarto's seamless integration with Python, R, Julia, and Observable, enabling dynamic content generation and interactive data exploration

![rstudio-qmd-how-it-works.png (1400Ã—257) (quarto.org)](https://quarto.org/docs/get-started/hello/images/rstudio-qmd-how-it-works.png)

## Running Code

When you click the **Render** button a document will be generated that includes both content and the output of embedded code. You can embed code like this:

```{r}
#| echo: true
1 + 1
```

::: aside
[Check other execution options](https://quarto.org/docs/computations/execution-options.html)
:::

```{mermaid}
%%| label: fig-mermaid

%%|   How Quarto orchestrates rendering of documents: start with 
%%|   a qmd file, use the Knitr or Jupyter engine to perform the 
%%|   computations and convert it to an md file, then use Pandoc 
%%|   to convert to various file formats including HTML, PDF, 
%%|   and Word.
flowchart LR
  A[qmd] --> B(Knitr)
  A[qmd] --> C(Jupyter)
  B(Knitr) --> D[md]
  C(Jupyter) --> D[md]
  D[md] --> E(pandoc)
  E(pandoc) --> F(HTML)
  E(pandoc) --> G(PDF)
  E(pandoc) --> H(Word)
  E(pandoc) --> I{and more}
```

## Slide Code 1

```{.python code-line-numbers="6-8"}
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

r = np.arange(0, 2, 0.01)
theta = 2 * np.pi * r
fig, ax = plt.subplots(subplot_kw={'projection': 'polar'})
ax.plot(theta, r)
ax.set_rticks([0.5, 1, 1.5, 2])
ax.grid(True)
plt.show()
```
